You know what? I am a failed guitarist. When I was a kid, I made the mistake of settling for a cheap guitar rather than saving my pennies and getting a bass like I really wanted. I had tried out a bass in music class in middle school and loved. But I had the choice of getting a guitar now, or save until I had the difference between the price of the guitar that my parents were willing to pay, and what a bass costed. (This was the early 70s, there were not many inexpensive basses on the market that I knew of like was true a decade later.) I suppose part of that was I just didn’t see how I was going to save the extra money. What little I did have from chores, mowing, and even cleaning the local pizza place didn’t add up to much. So I got a guitar, even learned to play things on it. But I decided I just didn’t like it much. And now my “I want to buy X instrument” well was dry. So I finally got a bass about 8 years later and learned to play it. I never was anything but a journeyman player, but I had fun and had more than one chance to turn professional.

I believe bass is a totally different entity from guitar. Can a guitarist pick up a bass? Sure but it won’t really make them a bassist and it may become obvious to actual bass players right off the bat that this person is primarily a guitarist. That being said no bassists are not failed guitar players because of the reasons aforementioned above. There are many bassists who put in their own unique style to further define the instrument as its own.
A select few are, but I wouldn't say failed. Maybe just not incredibly efficient at guitar. That said a “real” bassist is completely different. I've seen people play bass like EVH plays guitar.
